quotes.quote: I have a new found respect for women who have been through breast cancer and this surgery.
Once I overcame breast cancer, I wasn't afraid of anything anymore.
Whether you're a mother or father, or a husband or a son, or a niece or a nephew or uncle, breast cancer doesn't discriminate.

Breast cancer is not just a disease that strikes at women. It strikes at the very heart of who we are as women: how others perceive us, how we perceive ourselves, how we live, work and raise our families-or whether we do these things at all.
Life after breast cancer can go back to normal. It's just the normal that has changed.
Cancer is a word, not a sentence.
You can be a victim of cancer, or a survivor of cancer. It's a mindset.
I had cancer, cancer never had me.
There can be life after breast cancer. The prerequisite is early detection.
Keep your sunny side up, keep yourself beautiful, and indulge yourself.
You beat cancer by how you live, why you live and in the manner in which you live.
Having cancer does make you try to be better at everything you do and enjoy every moment. It changes you forever. But it can be a positive change.
Don't let breast cancer take away the motivation to achieve your dreams.
If you have any doubt, go back againâ€¦ Because someone is in a white coat and using big medical instruments doesn't necessarily mean they're right
Cancer can touch you, but not your soul; neither your thoughts, nor your heart.
Breast cancer changes you, and the change can be beautiful.
Cancer may have started the fight, but I will finish it.
Breast cancer is scary and no one understands that like another woman who has gone through it too.
If you have a friend or family member with breast cancer, try not to look at her with â€˜sad eyes.' Treat her like you always did; just show a little extra love.
I have surgery scars, but I consider them battle scars.
Love and laughter are two of the most important universal cancer treatments on the planet. Overdose on them.
The only thing we have to fear is fear itself. So the only thing to really be afraid of is if you don't go get your mammograms.
It's about focusing on the fight and not the fright.
Whenever women struggle with breast cancer and face better care than ever, that's feminism.
Fight each round take it on the chin. And never never never ever give in.
The most important thing in illness is never to lose heart.
I've always thought of myself as being a warrior. When you actually have a battle, it's better than when you don't know who to fight.
Cancer is WAY too serious to be taken seriously all the time.
I believe that breast cancer will soon become something we live with rather than die fromâ€¦
Show you care. Be aware.
The death clock is ticking slowly in our breast, and each drop of blood measures its time, and our life is a lingering fever.
Never be ashamed of a scar. It simply means you were stronger than whatever tried to hurt you.
Whoever said winning isn't everything, obviously wasn't fighting breast cancer.
I have cancer. Cancer doesn't have me.
When someone has cancer, the whole family & everyone who loves them does, too.
October is breast cancer awareness month, but for a survivor, it's every single day.
Joy shouldn't go away because you have cancer.
No matter what the statistics say, there is always a way.
You have been assigned this mountain, to show others it can be moved.
Cancer does not have a face until it's yours or someone you know.
